Below are some common ways, you can use to fetch data from an API in 
javaScript ðª

   - *Using the fetch API: * 
      - The fetch API is a modern built-in feature of browsers and Node.js 
      that provides a way to make asynchronous network requests. 
      - fetch returns a Promise that resolves to the response from the 
      server, making it easy to work with asynchronous code using .then() and 
      .catch(). 
   - *Using the Axios library: * 
      - Axios is a widely used third-party library that simplifies HTTP 
      requests, providing features like automatic JSON parsing and request 
      cancellation. 
      - Axios is versatile and can be used in both browser and Node.js 
      environments, making it suitable for various JavaScript projects. 
   - *Using the XMLHttpRequest object:* 
      - XMLHttpRequest is an older method for making requests, providing 
      more manual control but also being more verbose compared to newer 
      alternatives like fetch. 
      - Despite its age, XMLHttpRequest is still widely supported in older 
      browsers, making it useful for projects that need to cater to older browser 
      versions. 
   - *Using the jQuery library:* 
      - jQuery's AJAX methods provide a simplified syntax for making 
      requests, abstracting some of the complexities of working with the native 
      XMLHttpRequest or fetch.

Subject: Frontend to Fullstack Monthly #13 âÂ How should masonry work in CSS?
Message:
What's new in May 2024? Get up to speed with what's going on in front-end, Node.js and beyond.

Hi Maheswara,

We're back with Frontend to Fullstack Monthly #13 â new courses, updates, and all the industry's latest news!

--------------------------------------
Frontend Masters Boost (From the Blog)
--------------------------------------

Boost has been busy this month bringing you articles on all sorts of web platform features and news. We've also shipped a freshened up design, leaning into GitHub's open source Mona Sans ( https://github.com/mona-sans ) , a variable font that certainly seems up to the task of typography on a tech blog.

The aspect-ratio property in CSS is super useful and has been supported in all browsers for quite a while now, but it doesn't take much for it to not work as expected. If this is happening to you, here's what might be going on ( https://frontendmasters.com/blog/things-that-can-break-aspect-ratio-in-css/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ). WeÂ prefer the fundamentals at Frontend Masters; vanilla HTML, CSS, and JavaScript will always serve you well. Here's an easy grab-and-go search form ( https://frontendmasters.com/blog/the-html-css-and-svg-for-a-classic-search-form/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ) using just the vanilla tech you need. The Popover API is now available ( https://frontendmasters.com/blog/popover-api-is-here/ ) across browsers and personally I'm most excited about using it for tooltips ( https://frontendmasters.com/blog/using-the-popover-api-for-html-tooltips/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ).

We'd also like to welcome some new guest authors, like Adam Rackis who introduces us to the versatile Auth.js ( https://frontendmasters.com/blog/using-nextauth-now-auth-js-with-sveltekit/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ) library and in this case use it with Svelte. Ben Hong did an exemplary job showing us the landscape of tools around Vue ( https://frontendmasters.com/blog/the-vue-ecosystem-in-2024/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ) right now. Preethi Sam gets awfully clever ( https://frontendmasters.com/blog/using-css-scroll-driven-animations-for-section-based-scroll-progress-indicators/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ) with Scroll-Driven Animations making section-based scroll progress indicators.

------------------------
Frontend Masters Courses
------------------------

We launched two new courses: Building Go Apps that Scale on AWS ( https://frontendmasters.com/courses/go-aws/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ) and Everything You Need to Know About Git ( https://frontendmasters.com/courses/everything-git/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ). We have recorded a ton of courses recently and will be releasing at least four more this month.

And we've been in the studio cooking up tons of new courses! They are recorded as live workshops ( https://frontendmasters.com/workshops/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs12 ) , and then edited into courses. Hope you can join us!

-----------------------
Industry news & updates
-----------------------

The first beta of React 19 ( https://react.dev/blog/2024/04/25/react-19 ) landed at the end of April with, notably, full support for Custom Elements. It's targeted at library and tool developers to get prepared for a final v19 release, but you can always upgrade if you want.. ( https://react.dev/blog/2024/04/25/react-19-upgrade-guide )

The WebKit ( https://webkit.org/blog/15269/help-us-invent-masonry-layouts-for-css-grid-level-3/ ) and Chrome ( https://developer.chrome.com/blog/masonry?hl=en ) teams are at odds on how best to implement so-called masonry-style layouts in CSS. Chris Coyier gives his take on Boost ( https://frontendmasters.com/blog/feedback-on-masonry-layout/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ).

Node.js 22 ( https://nodejs.org/en/blog/announcements/v22-release-announce ) arrived as the new 'current' branch of Node.js and is due to become the active LTS version later this year. It now has a WebSocket client enabled by default, watch mode is considered stable, and you can now run npm scripts more quickly using its --run option. FYI if you want to get up to speed with Node, we have an entire learning path for Node.js ( https://frontendmasters.com/learn/node-js/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ).

Ryan Dahl is keen to stress that JSR is not a new package manager ( https://deno.com/blog/jsr-is-not-another-package-manager ) or replacement for npm , but part of a fundamental shift in how packages are distributed â tailored for the modern ES modules era.

Google has delayed the end of third-party cookies in Chrome ( https://privacysandbox.com/intl/en_us/news/update-on-the-plan-for-phase-out-of-third-party-cookies-on-chrome/ ) yet again.

Here's what work is being carried out ( https://blog.jquery.com/2024/04/17/upgrading-jquery-working-towards-a-healthy-web/ ) to keep jQuery up to date across the web. jQuery UI got a small new release too ( https://blog.jqueryui.com/2024/04/jquery-ui-1-13-3-released/ ) â there's plenty of life in jQuery yet.

â¨ Key releases you may want on your radar: Astro 4.7 ( https://astro.build/blog/astro-470/ ) , Svelte 5 RC ( https://svelte.dev/blog/svelte-5-release-candidate ) , Next.js 14.2 ( https://nextjs.org/blog/next-14-2 ) Electron 30.0 ( https://www.electronjs.org/blog/electron-30-0 ) , and version 2.0 ( https://quilljs.com ) of text-editor Quill.

----------------------------
Handy tutorials and articles
----------------------------

â­ï¸ Cody Lindley is back with another updated edition of the Frontend Handbook for us ( https://frontendmasters.com/guides/front-end-handbook/2024/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=fefs13 ). It's a free, in-depth, guide to the current web development landscape. It covers everything from code editors, CSS, UX, UI, popular tools and frameworks, performance, accessibility, testing, AI, and much much more. Biased maybe, but well worth a bookmark we reckon.

Did you know you can detect JavaScript support just in CSS ( https://ryanmulligan.dev/blog/detect-js-support-in-css/ ) ? It's all thanks to the scripting media query.

Here's a solid step-by-step instructional video (29 minutes) on â¶ï¸ digging into responsiveness issues ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cmtfM4emG5k ) in Chromeâs Performance Panel.

Daine Mawer explains how we can create fluid typography ( https://www.sitepoint.com/fluid-typography-css-clamp-function/ ) with the CSS clamp() function.

Alexis Kypridemos shows us how we convert plain text to encoded HTML ( https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2024/04/converting-text-encoded-html-vanilla-javascript/ ) with vanilla JavaScript.

---------------
Useful projects
---------------

Extension ( https://extension.js.org/ ) is a new, easy way to get started with building your own browser extensions. One terminal command and you're up and running.

Consent Banner JS ( https://github.com/tagconcierge/consent-banner-js ) is a zero-dependency, lightweight (~3KB) cookie banner.

TresJS ( https://tresjs.org ) can be used to create 3D scenes with Vue components and Three.js if you want to put together dynamic, striking visual experiences on the Web.

ð Unovis ( https://unovis.dev/ ) is a flexible data visualization framework that's happy working alongside React, Angular, Svelte, Vue or vanilla TypeScript/JavaScript. There are lots of examples ( https://unovis.dev/gallery ) , all with code.

Tagify ( https://yaireo.github.io/tagify/ ) is an elegant component for inputting tags.

This gallery ( https://csspro.com/css-gradients ) has over 250 click-to-copy CSS gradients.

Naming things (functions, classes, properties, etc) can be hard, this site sets out to help ( https://classnames.paulrobertlloyd.com ).

Thanks for reading â see you in the next one!

Medium's weekly newsletter Â - Â May 10, 2024

Hi,

Little-known fact: Motherâs Day in the U.S. began as a tribute to one mother, Ann Jarvis ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ann_Jarvis ). A community organizer who raised money to buy medicine and childcare for families in need, she died in 1905 before the second Sunday of May. Her daughter, Anna Jarvis, petitioned Congress for a national Motherâs Day as a way to keep her momâs memory alive.

Decades later, when Motherâs Day became more about buying flowers and greeting cards than actually connecting with your mom, Jarvis was irate ( https://archive.org/details/womenwhomadediff00malc/page/134/mode/2up ) : *âA printed card means nothing except that you are too lazy to write to the woman who has done more for you than anyone in the world,â* she fumed. In the â40s, she actually petitioned to revoke the holiday ( https://medium.com/p/7bb8abb54428?source=mktgemail-5c45319446fb--edition.user-------------------------cafad650_0ea1_11ef_92d1_a2f883c66d4a ) (!) but by then it had already caught on.

On Medium, youâll find over 10,000 stories about Motherâs Day ( https://medium.com/tag/mothers-day?source=mktgemail-5c45319446fb--edition.user-------------------------cafad650_0ea1_11ef_92d1_a2f883c66d4a ) , and most go much deeper than the platitudes on a greeting card. J.C. Anne Brown describes what she calls the â emotional fuzzy Velcro ( https://medium.com/p/242eeeaa2b22?source=mktgemail-5c45319446fb--edition.user-------------------------cafad650_0ea1_11ef_92d1_a2f883c66d4a ) â of obligation and guilt some associate with the day. Former Al Jazeera anchor Richelle Carey unpacks the complexity of being an adoptive mom ( https://medium.com/p/2d23158f7eee?source=mktgemail-5c45319446fb--edition.user-------------------------cafad650_0ea1_11ef_92d1_a2f883c66d4a ) , writing, âI understand the immense responsibility that comes with adoption, particularly because itâs a process that starts with someone elseâs difficult choice.â

And hereâs essayist Summer Block capturing the essence of a certain stage of motherhood these days: chauffeuring your kids around and feeling like an extra in the movie that is your life. Itâs nostalgic and poetic ( https://medium.com/p/8c2fb3d49598?source=mktgemail-5c45319446fb--edition.user-------------------------cafad650_0ea1_11ef_92d1_a2f883c66d4a ) :

The experience of driving a teenager and their friends is like that of being a ghost haunting your own life. I remembered my best friendâs mom, who always picked us up in a wood-paneled navy blue minivan, unfailingly cheerful, always playing the oldies station, always with an open can of Tab in the driverâs seat cup holder, asking if weâd had fun at the pool as we made a lot of loud, giddy jokes and draped sopping wet beach towels all over the upholstery of her car. Was it possible that she, too, was real?

Thanks for reading,
â Harris Sockel
